Name: Aloe Vera
What is it?: Cactus plant that belongs to the Liliaceae family
Contains two hormones (Auxin and Gibberellins) which provides wound healing and anti-inflammatory properties
Contains other antioxidants including, beta carotene, vitamin C and E
Key Benefits: Reduces skin inflammation such as itchiness and sun damage
Minimizes appearance of scarring and stretch marks
Improves skin's natural firness and keeps skin hydrated
When / How to Wear?: Apply a thin layer immediately following sun damage

Name: Alpha Hydroxy Acids (AHA)
What is it?: Water loving and water soluble acid
Key Benefits: Stimulates collagen production
Reduces appearance of fine lines and wrinkles
Dissolves the glue that holds dead skin cells together to exfoliate and reveal a brighter, smoother, even-toned skin underneath
Side Effects: Can irritate if you have sensitive skin. Start with low doses and build up amount and frequency
When / How to Wear?: Recommended for nighttime wear since it's an exfoliant
Who can use it?: Preferred for drier skin since this exfolidates at the surface of skin and have added component of improving moisture content
Extra Credit: Does not penetrate as deeply as BHA

Name: Alpha Lipoic Acid (ALA)
What is it?: Antioxidant enzyme soluable both in water and fat that can easily penetrate the skin
Key Benefits: Anti-inflammatory
Reduces swelling and puffiness
Fights free-radicals
Regulates production of nitric oxide, which controls blood flow to the skin and helps transforms the complexion from dull, pasty and pale to vibrant and glowing
Able to regenerate Vitamin C and E, enhancing their efficiency
Side Effects: High concentrations (5% or more) can cause burning and stinging
Extra Credit: 400x stronger than vitamins E and C combined (both of which are renowned for their antioxidant properties
All antioxidants degrade when exposed to light and air, but ALA is more vulnerable to this. Keep in dark, cool place

Name: Benzoyl Peroxide
Key Benefits: Antibacterial
Prevents breakouts

Name: Beta Hydroxy Acid (BHA)
What is it?: Oil-loving acid that exfolidates skin and penetrates deep into pores dissolving plugs of sebum and dead skin
Able to normalize lining of pore that contributes to acne
When / How to Wear?: Recommended for nighttime wear since it's an exfoliant
Extra Credit: Preferred for oily, acne-prone skin and for treating blackheads and whiteheads

Name: Biotin (Vitamin B7)
What is it?: Nutrient that helps body process fats and sugars while oral biotin is important for regulating hair and nail growth
Biotin must be present in order for body to convert nutients for proper functioning
Key Benefits: Treats weak hair and nails
Protects skin from acne and other skin issues

Name: Caffeine
What is it?: Constricts blood vessel and gives skin a firmer appearance
Contains antioxidant properties to help protect against free radicals
Key Benefits: Firming
Protection against UV radiation

Name: Ceramide
What is it?: Critical component of epidermis that holds skin cells together, forming a protective layer that plumps the skin and retains moisture
Replenishes the natural lipids that are lost from exposure to harsh environmental factors, overuse of drying products, and during the aging process
Key Benefits: Moisturizing and treating skin concerns such as eczema

Name: Charcoal
What is it?: A carbon that draws bacteria, poisons, chemicals, dirt and other micro-particles to the surface of skin
Key Benefits: Clears skin and fights breakouts
When / How to Wear?: Carbon needs to come in physical contact with impurities in order to soak them up, so the longer a product sits on your skin, the more effective it's going to be

Name: Chemical SPF
What is it?: Contains organic (carbon-based) compounds, such as oxybenzone, octinoxate, octisalate and avobenzone, which create a chemical reaction and work by changing UV rays into heat, then releasing that heat from the skin
Key Benefits: Sun protection
When / How to Wear?: AM: requires 20-minutes lead time

Name: Coenzyme q-10
What is it?: Fat-soluble compound present in all human cell (aka Ubiquinone)
Key Benefits: Fights free radicals
Expedites cell renewal and stimulates collagen production
Reduces UV damage
When / How to Wear?: PM:  depleted by sun exposure

Name: Collagen
What is it?: Naturally contains high concentration of hydroxyproline which serves to increase skin's moisture levels and smoothness
Important building block of elasticity
Key Benefits: Reduces appearance of fine lines and wrinkles
Keeps skin firm and evens out skin tone

Name: Copper
What is it?: Acts as a conveyance carrying nourishing proteins to damaged skin
Key Benefits: Enhances function of antioxidants
Assists removal of free radicals from skin
Promotes skin regeneration and production of collagen and elastin
Breaks down large collagen deposits and replace them with more normal-sized collagen to create smoother skin

Name: Dimethicone
What is it?: Forms a hydrating barrier on skin that helps secure natural moisture from exiting
Key Benefits: Hydrating effect
Plump up fine lines and wrinkles

Name: DMAE (Dimethylaminoethanol)
What is it?: Precursor to acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that causes muscles to contract and tighten under the skin
Key Benefits: Relaxes fine lines and wrinkles from sagging and drooping
Anti-inflammator effects that help reduce sun damage and improve skin tone

Name: Ferulic Acid
What is it?: Plant-based antioxidant that naturally occurs in plant-cell walls help keep skin healthy and improve texture & tone
Key Benefits: Prevent wrinkles and sun damage
Whitening properties to combat hyperpigmentation when paired with Vitamin E
Stablizes and enhances other antioxidants such as Vitamin C and E
When / How to Wear?: Pair with Vitamin C and E for enhanced benefits
Extra Credit: If you’re allergic to grains such as wheat, corn or barley, you should consult a doctor before using a product with this ingredient to avoid any negative reactions

Name: Glycolic Acid (AHA)
What is it?: Alpha Hydroxy Acids (AHA) that penetrates damaged skin to stimulate collagen production
Of the AHAs, GA has the strongest anti-aging properties and works more quickly/ effectively given it's molecule size
Key Benefits: Exfoliates skin while stimulating collagen production
Improves and heals sun damaged skin
Treats hyperpigmentation
Reduces visible signs of ageing
When / How to Wear?: Avoid when using retinol as AHA exfoliate skin
Recommended for nighttime wear since it's an exfoliant

Name: Hyaluronic Acid (HA)
What is it?: A molecule that occurs naturally in skin and helps retain water so skin remains plump
Able to boost skin’s moisture content, soothe, and defend against moisture loss
Key Benefits: Retains moisture and plumps the skin

Name: Hydroquinone
What is it?: Fades hyperpigmentation by blocking the enzyme that triggers melanin production in the skin
Key Benefits: Evens out sun spots, blotches

Name: Jojoba seed oil
What is it?: Liquid wax extracted from the seed of the Jojoba plant and has a similar consistency to sebum (natural oils found on face) which helps dissolve sebaceous secretions off body
Key Benefits: Can trick the skin into thinking it has produced enough oil and thus balance oil production, without promoting acne or other skin problems
Full of nutrients like Vitamin E and B, as well as antioxidants and minerals like chromium, copper, and zinc, which all nourish and protect skin & reduce signs of aging
Naturally deters microbes, which helps prevent the growth of bacteria on skin and helps those with acne & scarring problems
Penetrates deep into hair follicles and breaks down sebum & debris that has built up on the scalp
Extra Credit: Organic, cold-pressed, jojoba oil has the highest level of antioxidants and nutrients
Very stable oil, with a shelf life of up to two years

Name: Kojic Acid
What is it?: Chemical derived from mushrooms and can also be created during the sake brewing process from fermented rice
Key Benefits: Lightens skin discoloration such as age & dark spots, freckles
Side Effects: Can irritate skin if you have sensitive skin. Start with low concentrations and build up dose and frequency.
When / How to Wear?: Causes sun sensitivity so use with SPF or at night
Mainly should be used to fade discoloration that wasn't originally on your skin (e.g. age spots, sun spots, or post-breakout marks)
Extra Credit: Unstable and oxidize rapidly. When it is exposed to air, it turns into a shade of brown and loses its efficacy.

Name: Lactic Acid (AHA)
What is it?: Type of Alpha Hydroxy Acids (AHA) that chemically exfoliates but isn't as drying as glycolic acid
Key Benefits: Exfolidates skin while stimulating collagen production
Improves sundamaged skin
Treats hyperpigmentation
Reduces visible signs of ageing
When / How to Wear?: Avoid when using retinol as this exfoliates skin
Recommended for nighttime wear since it's an exfoliant
Who can use it?: A gentler option for those with sensitive skin and are unable to use harsher Alpha Hydroxy Acids
Extra Credit: Doesn't penetrate skin as well given its larger molecule size

Name: Macadamia Nut Oil
What is it?: Lightweight oil extracted from macadamia nut that is high in monounsaturated fatty acids
Key Benefits: Helps to restore the skin’s barrier function and reduce water loss
Contains one of the highest sources of Palmitoleic Acid (of all oils) which is an active anti-microbial that is found naturally in youthful skin
Improve appearance of scars, sunburn and other minor skin irritations
Extra Credit: Very stable oil, with a shelf life of up to two years

Name: Malic Acid
What is it?: AHA naturally found in body that can boost immune system and balance pH levels
Key Benefits: Improves appearance of fine lines, large pores
Improves overall texture of skin

Name: Manuka Honey
What is it?: Higher therapeutic properties than other honey varieties (Vitamin B, C, live enzymes)
Able to fight against metalloproteinases (MMP), enzymes that destroy collagen
Key Benefits: Moisturizing and softening
Reduces redness and heals congested or inflamed skin
Oxygenates pores to draw out bacteria
Increases collagen cross-linking and promotes growth of collagen in skin cells
Extra Credit: Often graded as "12+ or "16+," which indicates its concentration of beneficial compounds and antioxidants, so the higher the number, the stronger the antibiotic effect

Name: Niacinamide
What is it?: A form of Vitamin B3
Key Benefits: Increases ceramid and free fatty acid levels in skin while reducing water loss
Suppresses melanin from reaching skin surface
Reduce hyperpigmentation
Soothe rosacea
Treat acne
Improves skin barrier function
Reduces transepidermal water loss
When / How to Wear?: Avoid using with Vitamin C
Extra Credit: Even more effective than white petrolatum (vaseline) at reducing water loss and increasing moisture levels in the skin
More natural way of treating hyperpigmentation than hydroquinone

Name: Pearl
What is it?: Contains an antioxidant that boosts the efficacy of superoxide dismutase, one of the strongest antioxidant enzymes in the body
Rich in amino acids and more than 30 trace minerals to support health
The purest & most bio-available source of calcium
Helps to increase enzymes that neutralizes free radicals and regenerate collagen
Comprised of 30 to 80 percent calcium and they also contain magnesium, amino acids, and trace minerals
Key Benefits: Softens and increases elasticity of skin
Regenerates collagen
Reduces Redness
Helps reduce melasma and evens out skin tone

Name: Peptides
What is it?: As building-blocks for protein such as Collagen, peptides are able to send signals to collagen to prompt formation for youthful, supple skin
Key Benefits: Boosts collagen production
Speeds wound healing and mimic the effect of Botox when applied topically
When / How to Wear?: Best applied in serums or creams. Upkeep is important
Once you stop using them, you'll notice the difference
Extra Credit: Different types of peptides:
Matrixyl (aka peptide, palmitoyl-pentapeptide 3): collagen stimulating
Cooper Peptides: reduces inflammation
Neuropeptides: claim to relax facial muscle to reduce appearance of wrinkles
Similar to botox or Syn-ake (mimics venmo of the Asian Temple Snake)

Name: Physical SPF
What is it?: Contains Zinc Oxide and Titanium Dioxide which act as physical barriers to UVA and UVB with no wait time needed
Zinc Oxide protects against the entire UV range
Titanium Dioxide defends from all UVB and short UVA rays by reflecting and scattering the rays
Key Benefits: Sun protection
When / How to Wear?: AM
Extra Credit: Look for products that have Zinc Oxide and titanium for physical barriers from UVA and UVB rays

Name: Pitera
Key Benefits: Anti-aging, brightening, and purifying the skin

Name: Resveratrol
What is it?: A natual antioxidant compound found in high amounts amongst the skins of grapes and in red wine essential to neutralizing free radicals
Key Benefits: Fights free radicals and reduces fine lines and wrinkles

Name: Retin-A/ Retinoic Acid
What is it?: Prescription strength retinol
When / How to Wear?: Preferrably PM
Extra Credit: Prescription version of retinol that works faster and is more drying

Name: Retinol
What is it?: A form of Vitamin A that's been scientifically proven to reduce wrinkles you already have and the most easily absorbed by the body
Key Benefits: Acts as a protective shield and deflects free radicals from damaging our skin
Allows cells to produce more collagen and elastin (connective tissues that keep our skin tight and youthful) to create fresh new skin cells
Removes dead layers and the pore-clogging debris on the outer layer skin (aka the stratum corneum) while strengthening and thickening the epidermis
Interferes with the enzymes responsible for melanin production to keep skin bright and reduce hyperpigmentation
Decrease fine lines
Fights acne by decreasing oil production
Side Effects: Can irritate skin if you have sensitive skin. Start with low concentrations and build up dose and frequency.
When / How to Wear?: Preferrably PM
Avoid using with AHA/ BHA or Vitamin C
Pair with sunscreen
Who can use it?: Anyone as long as you can handle the concentration
Extra Credit: Retinol works best at a PH of 5.5-6.

Name: Rosehip oil
What is it?: A natural source of essential fatty acids, Vitamin A, C, E, and B which are vital to regenerating skin cells and repair damaged skin tissue
Contains 60-70% of linoleic acid which is an omega-6 fatty acid that moisturizes. Other oils only have 2-5% linoleic acid
Key Benefits: Minimizes sun damage (Vitamin C)
Protects and repairs skin from free radicals
Moisturizes skin
Improve skin texture and stretch marks (Vitamin A & E)
Extra Credit: Rosehip oil is different from rose oil (extracted from rose petals)

Name: Salicylic Acid (BHA)
What is it?: A lipid-soluble acid that penetrates into oily pores to exfoliate and clean from within
Key Benefits: Anti-inflammatory
Prevents breakouts
When / How to Wear?: Works well with Benzoyl Peroxide

Name: Shea Butter
Key Benefits: Helps seal in moisture in skin

Name: Tea Tree Oil
What is it?: Slightly yellow liquid derived from the Australian plant Malaleuca Alternifolia
Antimicrobial agent that kills P.Acnes, the bacteria that causes acne. Plus, it reduces inflammation. Guess what acne is? An inflammatory disease.
Key Benefits: Antiseptic and anti fungal properties
Antimicrobial agent that kills P.Acnes, the bacteria that causes acne. Plus, it reduces inflammation. Guess what acne is? An inflammatory disease.

Name: Vitamin C
What is it?: An antioxidant by donating electrons in order to neitralize free radicals created in skin after oxidative stress (aka sun damage)
Key Benefits: Stablizes, creates and improves the quality of collagen molecules in body"
Reduces the appearance of hyperpigmentation and discoloration caused by sun damage
Anti-aging
Brightening and evens out skintone
Anti-inflammatory for acne & rosacea prone skin
Side Effects: Can irritate skin if you have sensitive skin. Start with low concentrations and build up dose and frequency.
When / How to Wear?: PM
Avoid pairing with retinol and niacinamide
Pair with Vitamin E and ferulic acid for enhanced benefits
Extra Credit: Asorbic Acid products are recommended as they absorbs quickest and has the highest potency when applied topically

Applying vitamin C to the skin is 20 times more effective than oral ingestion

Absolutely need two ingredients:
Ascorbic Acid
Is your Vitamin C, brings all that collagen increasing, pigmentation fighting, antioxidant goodness to your skin
Tocopherol
Is your Vitamin E, since vitamin C is such a great antioxidant, it reacts with anything & everything since oxidants are everywhere.

Vitamin E prevents this from happening. Do note that this is NOT Tocopheryl Acetate, this converts to vit e in the skin, but in a solution it can't act as Tocopherol which stabilises the vitamin c. Ferulic acid does the same job as vit e as well, so combining the three creates a super stable vitamin c serum.

Vitamin C also needs to be at a pH of ~3 and at a concentration >15% to properly penetrate the skin, any higher of a pH and it can't absorb effectively.

Name: Vitamin E
When / How to Wear?: Pair with Vitamin C and ferulic acid for enhanced benefits

Name: Vitamin K
What is it?: Reverses calcium that is deposited in your skin’s elastin fibers, which harden and lead to wrinkles
Key Benefits: Reduces aging in skin
